[h3]💬 Comments 💬[/h3]
[h2]Short Game Description[/h2]
The Binding of Isaac is the original version of probably the best roguelike of all times, which presented a simple but very interesting idea with such a wide variety of enemies and items.
[list]
[*][h3]Positives[/h3]
Discussing the positives, first of all, the game idea achieved great, fun, and interesting gameplay to later originate the actual The Binding of Isaac: Repentance. Also, the artistic, hand-drawn style was quite decent. Secondly, the gameplay is challenging at the same time, as every run you play feels unique with all the different enemies and synergies. Thirdly, the soundtrack is great and makes it a better experience.
[*][h3]Negatives[/h3]
On the negative side, the problem with the original Isaac is that the difficulty spike is quite high, mostly because of the low variety of synergies and transformations that we have in the actual game. Also, the game runs at 30 FPS, which makes the experience even more rough. Too, the run can't be saved at any point, so if the game crashes or whatever happens, it can imply the loss of the entire run.
[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]
In short, there is no point in getting this game instead of The Binding Isaac: Rebirth because this game is just the base of something greater. The unique reason to get this game is just if you want to support the developer because of its great games and to try out how the original Isaac was. The game is a 6/10.

Character Variety (5/5): The different characters and their unique powers make every play experience different.

Weapon and Equipment Variety (4/5): The different weapon and equipment options strengthen the strategic aspect of the game, though some may be more effective than others.

Enemy Design (3/5): Enemy design is varied, but in some cases the difficulty can be unbalanced.

Boss Battles (5/5): Exciting boss battles become one of the most memorable moments of the game.

Rewards and Achievements (4/5): Rewards and achievements encourage player progression.

Play Time (4/5): Total play time is satisfying, but replayability ensures long-term enjoyment.

149020434.review:
Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill.

Isaac kept to himself, drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television.

Life was simple, and they were both happy. That was, until the day Isaac’s mom heard a voice from above.

“Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved.”

“I will do my best to save him, my Lord,” Isaac’s mother replied, rushing into Isaac’s room, removing all that was evil from his life.

Again the voice called to her, "Isaac’s soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins."

“I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in thee,” Isaac’s mother replied, as she locked Isaac in his room, away from the evils of the world.

One last time, Isaac’s mom heard the voice of God calling to her.

“You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you."

"Yes Lord, anything!” Isaac’s mother begged.

"To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life, as an offering to me to prove you love me above all else."

"Yes Lord", she replied, grabbing a butcher’s knife from the kitchen.

Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear.

Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trap door to the basement hidden under his rug.

Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down into the unknown depths below.

146277739.review:
[h1]This is not Isaac.[/h1]

Now, I know what you're saying. 'How could this not be Isaac? It says it right there, on the title!' But hold on, you're not understanding. This might be "The Binding of Isaac". This might be the predecessor to the beloved "Rebirth" remake/sequel. But this is sure as hell nothing like that game. 

I have dumped over 1k hours of my life in Rebirth, including all DLC's, that is, up to Repentance. I unlocked Dead God a year ago, at the time of writing this, and I'm currently on my second savefile. I know that game. I know what everything does; every item, every enemy, every machine and beggar; every nook and cranny. That game has virtually no secrets for me at this point. So there I was, yesterday, seeing the original flash version for sale on steam. 'Well --I thought to myself-- it's only two dollars, plus the expansion, that makes five. Might as well buy it and give it a try. It can't be that difficult.' 

One of the things that drove me the most toward Rebirth, when I started playing, was the story. I was really interested in that little Isaac kid and all the ways that the items he picked up reflected all the ways he was tortured at home. That is why it came as a surprise to me when I finally bought the game and, other than the extreme difficulty that entangles the base game --that completely goes away once you install any DLC-- the tone and overall atmosphere was very light and very much opposite to what I had expected. The pixel art aesthetic made the game look way more tame than its themes and story wanted to convince you it was. 

I kept playing. From PS4 I then went to Steam, starting from 0, but this time, with over 50 hours of experience. I easily beat Mom on my first, maybe second run. I was unstoppable. I was getting achievements left and right, and that moody atmosphere and dark story that first grabbed my attention were slowly being buried by all the knowledge that the game was forcing me to learn. I got Repentance on release date, and right away, I was looking up information about the new characters and items; on how to unlock them and what they each were. I was effectively optimizing my fun. The story was now entirely gone from my mind. I was merely looking at items, synergies, enemies. What goes with what, which one should I pick, who sould I kill first. 

Flash Isaac made me feel, for the first time, that sentiment that went away as my knowledge of Rebirth widened. This game, within the first few rooms, had made me feel vulnerable, scared and alone. None of the hours I had dumped on Rebirth would help me. For the first time in years, I couldn't even make it to the third floor without dying. This is not the same game I have spent five years playing. This is a whole different experience. Immediately I could feel that darkness upon entering the first room. Isaac is not a 16-bit little guy; Isaac is crying because Isaac is scared. Isaac is doing this because his mother is after him. Isaac is experiencing something that no one should ever have to go through. His situation is extremely unfair, and so is the game. Every room that you get yourself into will make you want to cry, because that second of Isaac's life is now become more painful than the last. After dying for the first time, I remembered an interview in which Edmund McMillen, the creator of this game, said something along the lines of 'With this game, I wanted to go all in, and fill it with all the stuff that they wouldn't let me add to Super Meat Boy'. I remembered his words about christianity, and how terrifying it was for a little kid to be scared on such a level of his omnipotent God. It suddenly made sense. All those people that seemingly prefer flash Isaac to the Far Superior Rebirth Plus DLC's. They were two different games. 

It was no help that, in my arrogance, I chose to start the game on hard mode, thinking that I would have no problem cruising through it. All those people saying 'Flash is harder', 'Flash is more unforgiving', 'In flash, it is actually difficult to get to Mom'. Oh, right? Watch me beating her on my first try.

I played 11 games on hard mode. Not only did I not beat mom a single time; I didn't even get to her floor. Eternal enemies were kicking my ass everytime I saw one, and I was finding it hard to get accustomed to the faster gameplay, and to the enemies that sometimes had more, and sometimes less health than I was used to. Everything was scary, and I was alone. 

Yes, this game is unfair, and very much so. There are a lot of room layouts in which damage is absolutely unavoidable. If Repentance's motto was 'All damage is avoidable', flash Isaac's should be exactly the contrary. And when I say this game is difficult, I mean it. People who have unlocked all achievements do not fuck around; beating hard mode with all characters is required, and that mode features something called 'eternal enemies', which are variants, recognisable for their entirely white color, that run faster, shoot larger quantities of faster projectiles, have loads and loads of health, and are, in general, and absolute pain in the ass. 

I cannot recommend this game to anyone new to the franchise. I cannot recommend this game to anyone whose enjoyement of Rebirth comes from breaking the game and ending every run having emptied the whole angel item pool. I cannot even begin to recommend this game to people who kind of liked Rebirth but wanted a more challenging experience. This one is seriously tough, and it has not aged well in any aspect. You can hear the flash engine cracking and wheezing every time you enter a new room, and in that aspect, it is very much a good thing that they decided to change the engine entirely for the remake. The people I [i]can[/i] recommend this to, though, are all the people who used to think about how the belt item makes you go faster because Isaac had to run from it, or how [strike]cricket's[/strike] max's head ups your damage because Isaac had never cried harder when they died. That, I think, is the type of people who will enjoy this sick and twisted game.

This game is nostalgia incarnate.

It feels so much better playing this masterpiece than the more recent installment of it.

Reasons I like this and why I will continue playing.

1: The music just [b] Slaps [/b], and I wouldn't have it any other way.
2: The sound design for basically every aspect of this game also hit really hard, and I [b] Love it [/b].
3: The game feels faster and is faster in more ways than one, making you actually sweat as you rush and dodge monsters/projectiles.
4: The difficulty skyrockets when [u] Hard Mode [/u] is enabled, because when they say [i] hard [/i], they mean it.
5: Speedrunable, despite having no in-game timer to work off of (though I wouldn't bat one eye at its competitive side).

So yeah... It's more than the best in my eyes, and I seriously doubt you'll be able to change my mind.

Yours truly, signing off!

145021861.review:
The game

Yo era un niño pequeño y disfrutaba de la vida, convivía con mi madre en la cima de una colina. Jugaba y dibujaba, diversión era mi esencia, sin dolor, preocupaciones, la edad de la inocencia.
Mi madre pasaba horas sentada al televisor, solo programas cristianos y referencias a Dios. Nuestra vida era sencilla, ambos éramos felices, hasta que una voz llamo a mi madre y dijo algo terrible.
"Tu hijo esta corrupto y tu misión es rescatarlo de todo elemento del diablo debes despojarlo".
"Hare lo que me pidas señor de mi vida, librare a Isaac de su alma corrompida"
Mi madre me ha quitado todo lo que poseía, mis juguetes, mis dibujos y la ropa que traía. Nunca dio explicaciones y jamás volvió a hablarme, pero se comunicaba con la voz perturbante.
"Isaac todavía sigue ligado por demonios que confiese sus pecados y aléjalo de todo".
"Hare lo que me pidas señor de mi vida, librare a Isaac de su alma corrompida"
¿Mamá por qué haces esto? Devuélveme mi vida, éramos felices y ahora sufro cada día. Por favor deja ya, no lo escuches más, pero de igual manera hubo un mensaje final.
"Has hecho lo que he dicho, pero cuestiono tu devoción. Probare tu Fé hacia mí con una última petición. Exijo un sacrificio y demuéstrame tu amor. Ve a la habitación de tu hijo y mátalo"
"Hare lo que me pidas señor de mi vida, librare a Isaac de su alma corrompida"
Entonces un cuchillo carnicero ella tomó, fue corriendo hacia Isaac que estaba en su habitación.
"¿Mamá que estás haciendo? ¿Por qué quieres matarme?"
Gritaba desesperado cuando la veía acercarse.
Gritos, llantos, locura y en su desesperación una puerta trampa bajo una alfombra encontró. Sin pensarlo dos veces la abrió al mismo tiempo que su madre ingresando a su habitación, pero Isaac se lanzó.
Se sintió a salvo, pero nada es sencillo ya que algo extraño sucumbía en todos los pasillos. Se acercó a una puerta y lentamente la abrió y repentinamente con sus hermanos se encontró.
Todos endemoniados y deformes, lo miraban. Con impulso vengativo a muerte lo atacaban. Isaac no lograba comprender la situación, sus lágrimas de pena son su última salvación.
Un pequeño que su inocencia perdió, una madre que por fanatismo enloqueció
Una marca eterna que conlleva a una cadena de desgracias y falacias al poder de la iglesia.
Un pequeño que su inocencia perdió, una madre que por fanatismo enloqueció
Una travesía de enfrentar a tus temores y vencer a aquel villano que tiene tu propia sangre.

144924671.review:
I think of this game as being one of the pioneers of a genre. Or at least it pushed things forward as far as roguelikes and their visibility. I remember watching multiple people on Youtube play this game and having the urge to play it myself. High accessibility and a "just one more run" type of addictiveness is present here. The randomly generated rooms are more often than not full of surprises. I would die unexpectedly and often. But just often enough some good luck would come my way in terms of effective boosts to attack power and interesting new abilities. The overall playstyle is rewarding and arresting. One naturally grows more skilled with each run. The story and thematic elements of this game however are a bit less savory. So on a subjective level I enjoy the themes of this game though they veer toward the macabre and disturbing. There is psychological horror here that is in-your-face. There is also a comical tongue-in-cheek element that is purposeful. Very original and not bad but not going to be everyone's cup of tea for sure which is fine. Overall, easily recommendable and fun. Maybe a bit herky-jerky and stiff in the controls department by 2023 standards.

Note : I played maybe 20+ hours of this game on PS4 in addition to the hours played on Steam.

143103685.review:
Title: The Binding of Isaac Original - A Dark and Addictive Rogue-like Gem

⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

The Binding of Isaac Original stands as a macabre masterpiece, a rogue-like dungeon crawler that has left an indelible mark on the gaming world with its dark narrative, challenging gameplay, and endless replayability. Developed by Edmund McMillen, the game's unique blend of disturbing themes and addictive mechanics has captivated players with its hauntingly memorable journey.

In The Binding of Isaac, you step into the shoes of Isaac, a young boy whose life takes a horrifying turn when his mother hears a disturbing voice instructing her to sacrifice her son. Escaping into the basement, Isaac must now navigate a labyrinth of procedurally generated rooms filled with grotesque monsters, nightmarish bosses, and a myriad of secrets to uncover.

The game's striking visuals set the tone for its unsettling atmosphere. Hand-drawn, grotesque creatures and dark, twisted environments create a world that oozes with eerie charm. Each floor's unique design adds an element of surprise, encouraging players to adapt their strategies to the ever-changing challenges that lie ahead.

The gameplay in The Binding of Isaac is unforgiving yet incredibly rewarding. As you progress, you'll unlock new items, power-ups, and characters, each altering your abilities and playstyle. The vast array of synergies between items keeps each run fresh and exciting, ensuring that no two playthroughs are ever the same.

The roguelike nature of the game means death is inevitable, but it's in failure that you learn and grow. Each defeat serves as a lesson, pushing you to experiment with different item combinations and approaches to overcome the twisted trials that await in the basement.

The Binding of Isaac Original's soundtrack perfectly complements the haunting ambiance. The chilling melodies and atmospheric sound effects immerse players deeper into Isaac's nightmarish world, enhancing the overall experience and adding to the emotional journey.

What truly sets The Binding of Isaac Original apart is its rich storytelling. Hidden throughout the game are cryptic messages, dark backstories, and enigmatic references that create an intricate narrative tapestry. The game's symbolism and themes delve into complex psychological and emotional territory, leaving players pondering long after the controller is set down.

The dedication of the developers to their creation is evident through the continuous support and expansion of the game. The Binding of Isaac Original has seen several expansions, each introducing new content, characters, and challenges, keeping the experience fresh and engaging for longtime fans and new players alike.

In conclusion, The Binding of Isaac Original is a dark and addictive rogue-like gem that transcends conventional gaming norms. Its combination of hauntingly beautiful visuals, challenging gameplay, and deep storytelling is a testament to the artistic vision of its creators. Whether you're drawn to its eerie aesthetic, strategic gameplay, or compelling narrative, this chilling descent into Isaac's tormenting world is a must-play experience for anyone seeking an unforgettable and enthralling gaming adventure.

Gallo Pinto Costarricense

Ingredientes
3 cucharadas de aceite de canola
1/4 cebolla picada
1/2 pimiento verde (o rojo) en cuadraditos
3 tazas de frijoles rojos o negros, cocidos
3 tazas de arroz blanco, cocido
1. pizca de Sal
2 cucharadas de culantro picado

Instrucciones
1. Calienta el aceite en una sartén grande y fríe la cebolla y el pimiento hasta que estén suaves.

3. Incorpora el arroz y sigue friendo unos tres minutos más agregando un poco más de caldo de frijoles para que el gallo pinto no quede muy seco y finalmente adorna con culantro picado.

142876744.review:
A classic roguelike, and famous for a reason! Full of wacky combos and weird baby body horror!

While there's many games in the genre that have since surpassed BoI, but it will always have a place in my heart for it's importance in the early formation of the genre and introducing me to rouglikes in general. 

Imo I enjoy this one a lot more than Rebirth. This might be an unpopular opinion, but I feel like like Rebirth got too bloated with the number of items, while simultaneously lowering the amount of ways things combo together. It feels like in this one having a bunch of game knowledge lets you manipulate things to great effect in your favor, while as in Rebirth having that game knowledge doesn't give you that cathartic feeling of outsmarting the game or making the best of a bad hand, and is instead the minimum needed and harder content is tediously difficult for no reason. 

I would recommend to anyone that's a fan of roguelikes, bullet hells, or zany item interactions.

142682581.review: I cannot believe I wasted 62 hours on this version of the game. DO NOT PLAY THIS TRASH, only play Rebirth and onward if you truly wish to enjoy this game as intended. If you want to painstakingly sit there and endure the complete bs this game constantly throws at you then kudos to you. To begin you have no say on your controls, you have to play with whatever default it gives you. So if you fat finger stuff a lot or have a small keyboard good luck, because you will constantly bomb yourself or use valuable cards/pills at the wrong time. The fullscreen is a joke, not only does it tank the fps, it also makes certain enemies harder to play against as they all of the sudden fire way more projectiles all around them that are downright impossible to dodge. You know what else is impossible to dodge though? Every enemy when it comes to specific room layouts which is the direct reason I quit this game. Whether you play on normal or hard mode (Which you have to play Hardmode to get all the achievements) you constantly run into rooms that I like to call "Death Rooms". These rooms have a layout that limits your movement to the point where you are automatically cornered the moment you enter the room. The enemies not only approach you to deal contact damage, but are also constantly firing mach speed projectiles all over the room. In front of you, behind you, everywhere. You have next to no immunity frames so you are taking 1-2 hearts of damage in like 1-1.5 seconds. If you have the patience to deal with this kind of thing, you may eventually get lucky enough to beat a run and get a few achievements. Problem is, you don't win this game with skill, you win only with luck, because you will constantly run into run ending rooms that you couldn't do anything about. Another thing is the bosses, most of them are insanely tedious or downright impossible to kill. They either bombard you with exploding projectiles, leave creep everywhere while spamming projectiles making it impossible to dodge after only seconds, or both at the same time while spawning unlimited amounts of tanky enemies. I literally had a decent run going only to run into Eternal War in the Eternal Challenge Room. I went from 6 full hearts and 2 soul hearts to half a heart over the course of 3 minutes with 4 damage and Technology Tears. The room was completely open, but he would literally dash every 3 seconds and spawn about 6-8 Globins. Once again I have Technology Tears which pierce through all enemies and it took me longer to kill the Globins then the time it took for him to spawn more. And he was spawning 5-6 troll bombs after the Globins. He was literally on screen for like 1 min of those 3 mins and that was mostly during the 2nd phase in which he charges at you faster then you can run while you are still surrounded by Globins. Once I finally killed him I picked up some extra hearts laying around and got 1 more soul heart, then headed to the boss room which I hadn't cleared yet. Can you guess who I saw when I entered? That's right another Eternal War!!! :DDDDD I paused the game, contemplated whether to play it out, saw the hearts I had and knew I was defeated. For a second however I was going to unpause and go out swinging, but I looked at the room layout and just alt F4'd. Rocks covering the corners, and the center of the room. So if you really want to play this game: 1. Don't play hardmode. 2. Don't expect to beat the final bosses even on normal mode for a long time due to the amount of runs you'll lose completely out of your control due to death rooms. I'm not going to waste my time and support for a game the devs didn't bother to make even remotely fair.

Luego de jugar 55 horas y haber conseguido todos los logros, puedo afirmar que el The Binding of Isaac de Flash es posiblemente el mejor juego con mayor cantidad de defectos que haya jugado hasta el momento.
El juego es muy divertido, difícil, con una cantidad decente de personajes y definitivamente una cantidad abundante de jefes y enemigos muy variados. El lore si bien no esta tan trabajado como en Repentance sigue siendo bastante interesante y la banda sonora no solo es mejor que su secuela si no que además se ha vuelto hasta icónica (destaco My Innermost Apocalypse al ser mi favorita). 
A pesar de todo esto, el juego presenta muchos errores, como su pésima optimización, el spawn de llaves que es casi inexistente, la enorme cantidad de items malos, la inexistencia de sinergias, el mal diseño de algunas salas que, a menos que vueles, es imposible no recibir daño y, lo que para mi es lo peor, el modo difícil integrado en la Eternal Edition, el cual es injusto en muchos niveles y es posiblemente el peor modo difícil que he jugado en mi vida, cada jefe e incluso enemigo común eterno parece un mini Delirium, y los ataques teledirigidos son casi imposibles de esquivar, y si bien esto se compensa con una gran cantidad de corazones blancos, no es una experiencia agradable.
En resumen: El juego es muy bueno, es un desafío terminarlo al 100% y, a pesar de todos los fallos que he mencionado anteriormente, puedo recomendarlo completamente si te gustan los juegos difíciles o con temáticas oscuras y tétricas.

Completar este juego al 100% me consumió todo ápice de cordura. Debería Bañarme.

Yo era un niño pequeño y disfrutaba de la vida, convivía con mi madre en la cima de una colina. Jugaba y dibujaba, diversión era mi esencia, sin dolor, preocupaciones, la edad de la inocencia.
Mi madre pasaba horas sentada al televisor, solo programas cristianos y referencias a Dios. Nuestra vida era sencilla, ambos éramos felices, hasta que una voz llamo a mi madre y dijo algo terrible.
"Tu hijo esta corrupto y tu misión es rescatarlo de todo elemento del diablo debes despojarlo".
"Hare lo que me pidas señor de mi vida, librare a Isaac de su alma corrompida"
Mi madre me ha quitado todo lo que poseía, mis juguetes, mis dibujos y la ropa que traía. Nunca dio explicaciones y jamás volvió a hablarme, pero se comunicaba con la voz perturbante.
"Isaac todavía sigue ligado por demonios que confiese sus pecados y aléjalo de todo".
"Hare lo que me pidas señor de mi vida, librare a Isaac de su alma corrompida"
¿Mamá por qué haces esto? Devuélveme mi vida, éramos felices y ahora sufro cada día. Por favor deja ya, no lo escuches más, pero de igual manera hubo un mensaje final.
"Has hecho lo que he dicho, pero cuestiono tu devoción. Probare tu Fé hacia mí con una última petición. Exijo un sacrificio y demuéstrame tu amor. Ve a la habitación de tu hijo y mátalo"
"Hare lo que me pidas señor de mi vida, librare a Isaac de su alma corrompida"
Entonces un cuchillo carnicero ella tomó, fue corriendo hacia Isaac que estaba en su habitación.
"¿Mamá que estás haciendo? ¿Por qué quieres matarme?"
Gritaba desesperado cuando la veía acercarse.
Gritos, llantos, locura y en su desesperación una puerta trampa bajo una alfombra encontró. Sin pensarlo dos veces la abrió al mismo tiempo que su madre ingresando a su habitación, pero Isaac se lanzó.
Se sintió a salvo, pero nada es sencillo ya que algo extraño sucumbía en todos los pasillos. Se acercó a una puerta y lentamente la abrió y repentinamente con sus hermanos se encontró.
Todos endemoniados y deformes, lo miraban. Con impulso vengativo a muerte lo atacaban. Isaac no lograba comprender la situación, sus lágrimas de pena son su última salvación.
Un pequeño que su inocencia perdió, una madre que por fanatismo enloqueció
Una marca eterna que conlleva a una cadena de desgracias y falacias al poder de la iglesia.
Un pequeño que su inocencia perdió, una madre que por fanatismo enloqueció
Una travesía de enfrentar a tus temores y vencer a aquel villano que tiene tu propia sangre.

141851856.review:
(i have two account with The Binding of Isacc and this is my final review)
I've played Isaac for about 200 hours, and I can say that it's a delightful experience. Each game generates a random map with a staggering variety of items. There are 17 initial characters, each with their unique abilities, and the compatibility between different items adds to the game's high replayability. The gameplay itself is simple and easy to grasp, but mastering the game takes a long time.

Isaac is highly randomized, from map generation to item rooms, devil rooms, angel rooms, and the quality of items in the shops. Even the enemy placement on each floor is random. Therefore, in my opinion, each run depends not only on the player's skill but also on luck. A powerful Tier 4 item from an item room, like Sacred Heart or Brimstone, can significantly alter the course of the game. Additionally, players need to make choices and trade-offs. Should they use their heart containers to obtain items from devil rooms? Which of the many strong active items should they prioritize for maximum benefit? There may be other aspects that I, as a novice, am not aware of yet.

Currently, I play Isaac for a couple of runs every day before diving into other games. I take the achievements as they come and don't focus on them too much.

With the amount of randomness and absurd number of item combinations The Binding of Isaac offers, you’ll never have the same run twice. 140755741.review:
The Binding of Isaac is a rogue-like action-adventure game developed by Edmund McMillen and Florian Himsl. The game was released in 2011 and has since garnered a cult following for its unique gameplay, dark themes, and challenging difficulty.

The game follows the story of Isaac, a young boy who is forced to flee into a basement to escape his religiously fanatical mother. The basement is filled with monsters, traps, and other horrors, and Isaac must fight his way through the levels to reach the final boss and confront his fears.

The game's gameplay is a mix of action, exploration, and RPG elements. Players must navigate through randomly generated levels, defeating enemies and collecting power-ups along the way. The game also features a wide variety of bosses, each with their unique attacks and abilities, making each playthrough feel unique.

One of the standout features of The Binding of Isaac is its dark and twisted themes. The game explores themes of child abuse, religion, and mental illness, making it an intense and thought-provoking experience. The game's art style is also unique, featuring grotesque and disturbing imagery that perfectly captures the game's tone.

The game's difficulty is another aspect that sets it apart from other games in the genre. The game is challenging, with players needing to master the game's mechanics and learn enemy patterns to progress. This can be frustrating at times, but it also makes each victory feel that much more satisfying.

Overall, The Binding of Isaac is a challenging and thought-provoking game that will appeal to fans of the rogue-like genre. Its dark themes and unique art style make it a standout game, and its challenging difficulty will keep players coming back for more. If you're looking for a game that's not afraid to explore dark and twisted themes, The Binding of Isaac is definitely worth checking out.

140627126.review:
[h1]The Binding of Isaac[/h1]

[b]The Original Version Of The Definitive Flash-Era Roguelite[/b]

[b]The Binding of Isaac[/b] is now 12 years old, which is a pretty crazy thing to me. While I didn't play this original version until now, I had played the [b]Rebirth[/b] remaster a lot when I first got my PS4. That game was likely the first true roguelite I had ever played. Revisiting this original version makes it clear where the game placed its roots, but it also shows how inferior the first version was.

The interesting thing about Isaac is how much it replicates the original [b]The Legend of Zelda[/b] with its dungeon design. This never occurred to me until I recently played the first LoZ game, but it's a core component of this game with its focus on ranged combat, bombs, keys, and the way dungeons and enemies are structured. It's a nice evolution of a pretty early adventure game idea.

The actual gameplay of Isaac is pretty simple but does devolve into a repetitive yet addicting loop. You defeat a room full of enemies to progress throughout a randomized dungeon, and you collect primary items and other secondary-use items along the way. This changes how Isaac's character functions and offers some wacky tools to fight enemies with. A downside is that you cannot get rid of items you don't enjoy, and there are no in-game descriptions for any items, causing you to have to memorize each one (unless you have a wiki pulled up next to you).

The game is also very, very focused on randomness. There isn't a lot of room for skill, so you pretty much just work with what you're given. I find this game to lean too far into the "luck" side of things more often than not, which really takes away from the feeling of accomplishment.

Still, it's a fun game with some imaginative items, enemies, and boss fights. Future expansions/remasters would only make the game stronger, but this base version is still playable for those who are interested in seeing the earlier days of this game.

[h2]Final Verdict: 6/10 (Above Average)[/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

139726694.review:
[b]PROS:[/b]
+ super interesting lore
+ fun(ny) gameplay
+ cool boss fights
+ feeling of exploration
+ a ton of unlockable items
+ a ton of collectible items

[b]CONS:[/b]
- no official gamepad support
- Steam Cloud save issues
- achievement unlock issues
- fps drops in hardmode
- replaced by The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth

[b]Comment:[/b]
The Binding of Isaac is a disturbingly funny game with a lot of cute but very morbid gameplay. The enemies are something to behold, especially the bosses, and the creators really went in with a "let's crank up the levels of disgust" attitude. But in a good way! It fits in very well with the flash graphics (the game originally was just a flash game) and overall the art style is unique and memorable. There is a surprising amount of lore sprinkled throughout the whole thing. From locations to enemies to playable characters and even items/trinkets have their own idea behind them. It's a very biblical game but I don't see it as either praise or satire, more neutral - it just sprinkles in various parts and leaves it up to you what you think. Now to the main part - [u]how it plays[/u]: well, it's a really REALLY difficult game. Don't let the casual look fool you it is merciless from the start and only gets easier as you unlock new items ... but then again you unlock new harder levels too so it stays challenging. You can become good at it, learn all there is ... but most of the time what makes or breaks your run is what items are generated for you. You can struggle with bad ones or become OP with others. It can feel unfair at first but after you get the rhythm you can manage your time based on what run looks good or not. But you will die ... a lot ... often during late game boss fights. However, if you cherish the journey, what you gathered along the way, you will have fun. Sadly, there are a lot of technical limitations. No gamepad support (you need third party apps like JoyToKey). Achievements pop up weirdly. Sometimes during play, often after restarting the game. And a couple of times the game time didn't add while playing, like Steam forgot the game is on. Steam cloud works super wonky, as the unlocks (serial.txt) and campaign progress (so.sol) are on two separate files in two separate paths. It was easier to copy files manually. Eternal Edition DLC (added with Wrath of the Lamb DLC) feels unnecessary. It breaks the mods, it doesn't add items and just adds a layer of sponge-like enemies. Sure the attacks are different too but that makes the game more of a bullet-hell than it was. There are also extra glitches and fps drops in hardmode. This is a great game but it has been overhauled and remade to become a bigger and (possibly) better game in [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/250900/The_Binding_of_Isaac_Rebirth/]The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth[/url] (and it's DLCs). The community moved over there as well. So, while I like this art style more, I recommend going for the newer version(s) instead of this one...

[b]*Note:[/b] There is a limited modding tool available for this game. The Eternal Edition has no mod support. To disable this version and use normal WotL (which is needed for mods) go to "Manage My DLCs" and un-check "The Binding of Isaac Wrath of the Lamb Eternal Edition". To use the latest version you will need:
[list]
[*]SpiderMod v0.9.1 (WotL 1.48 only) - https://archive.org/details/SpiderMod-0.9.1
[*]Special Flash version (Install in Windows 7 compatibility mode) - https://archive.org/download/flashplayer_old/flashplayer32_0r0_371_winax.exe
[*]Community Remix Mod v1.3.2 (replaces IsaacSpiderMod.isc in The Binding Of Isaac/Data folder) - https://archive.org/details/community-remix-1.3.2
[/list]

139655738.review:
The Binding of Isaac: A Twisted Twin Stick Shooter Adventure

Review:
The Binding of Isaac is an incredibly twisted and captivating twin stick shooter that delves into dark themes, offers an abundance of items, and weaves a sick and twisted story that will leave you both disturbed and intrigued. This game truly stands out from the crowd, earning a well-deserved place in the hearts of many gamers.

One of the most impressive aspects of The Binding of Isaac is its vast array of items and synergies. As you progress through the game, you'll encounter countless power-ups and upgrades that can drastically alter your playstyle. The combinations and synergies between these items are nothing short of astounding, offering a level of depth and variety that keeps every run feeling fresh and exciting. The sheer amount of possibilities ensures that no two playthroughs are alike.

The game's dark and twisted narrative is another highlight. Centered around Isaac, a young boy escaping from his abusive mother, The Binding of Isaac delves into religious symbolism, exploring themes of sin, redemption, and the horrors that lie within one's own mind. The story is presented in a unique and atmospheric manner, leaving players with a lingering sense of unease and curiosity.

Visually, The Binding of Isaac features a distinct art style that perfectly complements its dark tone. The grotesque and macabre character designs, combined with eerie environments, create a haunting atmosphere that enhances the overall experience. The game's sound design further contributes to the unsettling ambiance, with a haunting soundtrack and chilling sound effects that immerse you in Isaac's twisted world.

While The Binding of Isaac offers a rich and immersive experience, it's important to note that its difficulty can be punishing. The game's roguelike nature means that each run is a new challenge, and success often requires strategic thinking, quick reflexes, and a bit of luck. Some players may find the difficulty curve to be a bit steep, but for those who enjoy a challenge, it adds to the overall satisfaction of overcoming the game's obstacles.

In conclusion, The Binding of Isaac is a twisted and enthralling twin stick shooter that immerses players in a sick and twisted world. Its extensive item pool, synergies, and deep narrative provide a captivating gameplay experience. While its difficulty may not appeal to everyone, those who appreciate its dark themes and challenging gameplay will find themselves drawn into its twisted web.

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐
A Twisted Twin Stick Shooter Adventure: The Binding of Isaac offers a unique blend of gameplay, dark storytelling, and atmospheric visuals. With its vast item pool, synergies, and challenging difficulty, it stands out as a memorable and intriguing experience, earning a solid 4/5 rating.

A masterpiece for its genius basic idea (making a game out of Zelda dungeons and an interlacing item system), but incredibly unfair and poorly balanced in every regard. There are some instances where you simply cannot avoid being hit, which is reason enough this doesn't get a thumb up! Also, some (all?) of the enemies that came with the DLC are incredibly difficult and annoying for their respective levels (unpredictable movement, additional effects like coin drain adding insult to injury). Jumpys are reason enough this doesn't get a thumb up. White flies are reason enough this doesn't get a thumb up. Greed is the biggest piece of shit I've ever seen in game development outside of Path of Exile, as it is a quadruple punishment – by far the hardest of the sins to avoid taking damage, taking away coins if it hits you, taking away the store for the floor (!), useless drops of either a few coins or the Steam sale which I've been able to actually use (on a later floor, i.e. not the same floor) fewer times than I have beaten the game's various end bosses!!! On the other hand, some items are so unbelievably overpowered (e.g. Epic Fetus, any flying item or certain combinations like Sacred Heart + a few Tears up, or turning into the cat + max tears item (which was it? I forgot). bam, hard mode chest win first try) you are basically guaranteed a win. In the end, this game feels more like a chore once you've beaten it a few times and have to get a win on every character (and they really aren't that different) against every boss. Oh, and even after 150 hours the stat system in the game doesn't make any sense to me. One damage upgrade (what item???), and my damage stat is maxed out. So why doesn't it feel like that, then? What did that shit actually do? Have numbers, not inexplicable symbols and meaningless counters. Also, the fact the game doesn't tell you what items do. I still have to look up trinkets, tarot cards, devil and angel room items in the wiki even after playing HUNDREDS of games! That's not good game design. Actually unlocking the item description in-game after picking it up for a certain number of times would have been motivating and an additional reward for playing you know. And gambling is often wayyy too slow. The pace is dead like Ed McMillen's cats when you have a lot of coins late in the game. Let me put in 10 coins at once ffs.

This would be a sideway thumb if Shteam allowed it because like I said, the basic premise is unbelievably good. The execution however is severely lacking. In many regards, this is the counterpart to Super Meat Boy, a likewise severely flawed classic (but not masterpiece). I really doubt the remake which I haven't played yet is any different – it's likely just much much larger.

Three (edit: FOUR) ideas how to make this much much better: 1. make rooms larger. one row and one column more would be enough to abate most unfair room layouts. 2. one optional boss room per level that lets you choose the reward (bomb, key, heart). It's SO FUCKING ANNOYING when I have to restart a run because I miss out on early blue heart stones or treasure rooms because I don't have a single bomb or key, and even worse when I got good items but am almost out of hearts in the sixth level or later. 3. EVERY character HAS to start with at least one key and one bomb. see 2 for why 4. The treasure room must be next to the starting room on Basement I. At least in hard mode, when you don't get a good item in the first treasure room, there is no reason not to reset instantly.

PS: and oh holy shit, the bugginess. There are seldom bugs in gameplay, but unlocks and achievements are really unreasonably bugged (like just right now I unlocked ???'s chest completion item when I beat hard mode chest with CAIN.) If Sh1team had any quality control (lol as if), this game would be removed.

PPS: Samson is a special kind of shit. I had to put that in the review. Fucking abomination of a design decision to make him so weak.

137596126.review:
In some ways easier than Rebirth, in others tougher. There's fewer synergies that completely break the game, but there's also fewer items in general so the consistency of runs is greater.

Hard mode is "f you" levels of hard with many enemies simply becoming bullethells on their own let alone when you get several of them at once, good luck if your character is lacking speed and/or damage ups. But hard mode is honestly really quite fun, you get the equivalent of Angel challenge rooms occasionally which give angel room items instead of the typical challenge room items, and I love how things like that make it a fairly different mode compared to normal runs in more than just "the enemies have more health now lol"

Runs are also fairly significantly shorter than Rebirth, likely in part there is not quite as much to do (shops and arcades aren't really worth it, but health ups from beggars very much are) which makes it good if you only have an hour or so to game.

Also I like the pausing on entering a room, stops me from running into floor spikes quite as much as I do in Repentance.

It's good. If you want more content on top of Rebirth, this isn't really treading any new ground aside from the hard mode. If you want a version of Isaac that's had a lot of the fat cut out and it's closer to its bare essentials however, this is probably worth a pick up even if you already have Rebirth. Menu controls are a bit shit in comparison but you get used to it :)

The Binding of Isaac is a game that is both hauntingly beautiful and disturbingly dark, yet manages to be an incredibly heartfelt experience that leaves a lasting impression on its players. This game is truly a masterpiece in every sense of the word.

The game follows the story of a young boy named Isaac who is forced to flee into his basement to escape from his overbearing and abusive mother, who believes she is doing God's work. In this basement, Isaac must navigate through various rooms and defeat horrific monsters to reach his ultimate goal: escape.

What makes The Binding of Isaac so special is its ability to blend horror, comedy, and emotion together seamlessly. Despite the game's disturbing visuals and themes, the story of Isaac is one of survival and hope. As players progress through the game, they uncover more of Isaac's backstory and learn about the challenges he has faced throughout his life.

But it's not just the story that makes The Binding of Isaac such a standout game. The gameplay itself is incredibly addicting, with players able to choose from a wide variety of power-ups and items that drastically change the way they play the game. Each run feels unique and different, and the game's replayability is second to none.

The art style and sound design of The Binding of Isaac are also worth mentioning. The game's pixel art is both charming and unsettling, and the soundtrack perfectly complements the game's dark atmosphere.

Overall, The Binding of Isaac is a game that is both haunting and heartwarming, and one that is definitely worth experiencing. It's a game that manages to stay with you long after you've finished playing, and one that I would highly recommend to anyone looking for a deep, emotional experience. It's truly one of the best games I've ever played.

[h1] Traditional Haggis Recipe [/h1]

[u][b] Ingredients: [/b][/u]
- 1 ox bung
- 1.4kg lamb's pluck, (heart, lungs and liver)
- 500g of beef, or lamb trimmings or stewing steak
- 200g of suet
- 500g of oatmeal, (coarse)
- 2 tbsp of black pepper, ground
- 1 nutmeg, finely grated
- 4 tbsp of coriander seeds
- 4 tbsp of fine sea salt

[u][b] Directions: [/b][/u]
1. Rinse the whole pluck in cold water. Trim off any large pieces of fat and cut away the windpipe
2. Place in a good sized pot and cover with cold water. The lungs float, so keep submerged with a plate or a lid. Bring to the boil and skim the surface regularly. Gently simmer for 2 hours
3. Lift the meat from the pot with tongs or a slotted spoon, and rinse in cold water to remove any scum. Place into a bowl and leave to cool
4. Strain cooking liquid through a fine sieve and put back on the stove to reduce until you have roughly 500mL – 1L of stock. Leave to cool
5. Whilst the stock reduces, finely dice the cooked heart and lungs. Grate the liver using the coarse side of the grater. Finely dice the trimmings. Mix together in a large bowl, along with the suet, oatmeal and spices
6. Measure how much stock remains from cooking the pluck, and make up to 1L with cold water. When cool, add to the haggis mixture
7. To check the seasoning, pan fry a tablespoon of the mixture for 2–3 minutes and taste. Add any extra salt, pepper or spice if needed
8. Spoon the haggis mixture into the soaked, rinsed ox bung.  Be aware the filling swells as it cooks, so pack quite loosely, and keep a little bung at each end
9. When the haggis is the size required, expel any extra air, pinch, tie with string and cut with scissors
10. Tie the new end of the bung, and continue stuffing. Freeze any spare haggises
11. Before cooking, pierce the haggis several times with a needle. Place in a pan of cold water, and bring to the boil. Simmer for 1.5–2 hours. When ready, the internal temperature should read at least 74°C
12. Serve with mashed potatoes and swede. Or neeps and tatties

The Binding of Isaac, developed by Edmund McMillen and Florian Himsl, is a unique and addictive game that combines elements of roguelike and twin-stick shooter genres. The game's dark and twisted themes, challenging gameplay, and endless replayability make it a standout entry in the indie game scene.

The game's story follows Isaac, a young boy who is trapped in his basement by his deranged mother, as he fights his way through waves of grotesque creatures and bosses to escape. The game's narrative is told through a series of cryptic cutscenes and item descriptions, which add to the game's overall atmosphere of dread and unease.

The gameplay mechanics in The Binding of Isaac are superb, with a wide range of power-ups, items, and characters to unlock. The game's randomly generated levels and enemies offer endless replayability, and the game's challenging difficulty level keeps players coming back for more.

Overall, The Binding of Isaac is a unique and addictive game that is well worth playing for fans of the roguelike and twin-stick shooter genres. Its dark and twisted themes, challenging gameplay, and endless replayability make it a standout entry in the indie game scene.

TL;DR: The Binding of Isaac is a unique and addictive game that combines elements of roguelike and twin-stick shooter genres. The game's dark and twisted themes, challenging gameplay, and endless replayability make it a standout entry in the indie game scene. The randomly generated levels and enemies, combined with a wide range of power-ups and items to unlock, offer endless hours of fun for fans of the genre.

Again the voice called to her, "Isaac’s soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins."

“I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in thee,” Isaac’s mother replied, as she locked Isaac in his room, away from the evils of the world.

One last time, Isaac’s mom heard the voice of God calling to her.

“You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you."

"Yes Lord, anything!” Isaac’s mother begged.

"To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life, as an offering to me to prove you love me above all else."

"Yes Lord", she replied, grabbing a butcher’s knife from the kitchen.

Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear.

Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trap door to the basement hidden under his rug.

Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down into the unknown depths below.

133122415.review:
Well... It's been quite some time since I first played this game all the way some time in early 2012.
But today was the day I finally got all the achievements, after not having played the game for a good 8 years.

I can still remember my first few attemps. I was so bad, it took a good 15 tries to even SEE the first boss and another 20 tries to beat him.
Looking back, this was probably one of the most influential games in the early 2010s for me. And recently I had feeled the urge of completing this version of the game for the sake of it.
Little did I know when starting up the game, there was actually new content waiting for me. Having switched to Rebirth on its release I was fully unaware of the free Eternal-Update from 2015.
So, this felt like I visited an old friend who surprised me with a long awaited gift.

This version is not just the birthplace of a great game, but it still retained its place as a game in its own rights. Thanks to a developer finishing up what had been left and giving it a bit of content that is now fully unique to this version, you can have a completely new experience, despite going BACK to this game.

So, now I've finally reached the end of the journey presented by this game itself. But even that might not be the end of it. I will check out the modding communities' efforts. There might be quite a bit more to experience here and I'm so glad that this gem is being treated well after all this time.

In a future opportunity, maybe I will buy another game in the franchise.

That was, until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above. "Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved." "I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life. Again, the voice called to her. "Isaac's soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins." "I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in Thee," Isaac's mother replied, as she locked Isaac in his room away from the evils of the world. One last time, Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her. "You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to Me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you." "Yes, Lord. Anything," Isaac's mother begged. "To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life, as an offering to Me to prove you love Me above all else." "Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen. Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement, hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down into the unknown depths below.

125581101.review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

the binding of isaac is a 2011 roguelike developed by indie devs Edmund McMillen (super meat boy) and Florian Himsl only on PC. the best way to describe this game is like the legend of zelda on NES but it's a roguelike. not only is that already sound awesome, but the game itself is commonly referred to as one of the best roguelikes of all time, especially for the time it came out. now over a decade later, the genre has expanded and gotten better but for a solid while after this released it definitely was one of, if not the best roguelike of all time. there's tons of different power-ups and abilities while all being easy to understand and quick to learn. 'runs' are pretty short and the gameplay is tight and controls well. the plot is a humorous take on the biblical story of the same name. it's hard but still fun even when you get your ass kicked. getting this for less than 50 cents or even a dollar is absolutely insane and i recommend that deal to just about anyone, even the most casual of gamer.

124432442.review:
Not for the faint of heart, let that be clear. This is as hardcore as games get. You will die when you start playing, but in the end you will get better. Still, getting to the end isn't a certainty. If you're a perfectionist wishing to get all challenges, I would definitely NOT recommend this game as it is a true challenge that might not be too healthy for you at times, haha. 

The random aspect of the items picked is a very important part of the game and makes every playthrough different. However, I recommend keeping a browser open with an item sheet or even a damage/synergy calculator to see how a pickup will influence your build. Because nothing is as annoying as picking up a run-breaking item. 

Be prepared to die (often), but experience a rewarding feeling when you build your skill and get better.

Writing this review in 2022 and this game still holds up, but there are better versions of it available and I would recommend those versions over this one.  They will allow some of the on screen limitations of number of enemies to be overcome.

That said the game is good fun.  A twin stick shooter roguelike with a disturbing and disgusting feel.  Lots of piles of poop everywhere and you fight other childlike creatures.  

Lots to see and unlock, you are constantly finding and unlocking new items, characters, or features.

Controls could be better, you can only shoot in cardinal directions, but you will learn to overcome this using the momentum of your character.

Soundtrack is great as well.

Overall a definite recommend, but get the newer versions as they have more.

121758495.review: The OG Binding of Isaac has aged... poorly when compared to the refined physics, functionality, and scope of Rebirth and its DLC, but I would like to give it credit for how well it set up everything to come. I sat my ass down awhile back to finally 100% it, and while there are some pretty obvious issues within it (usually relating to enemy patterns, especially in the Caves from what I remember), it's still quite a fun time all around. It's also interesting as a time capsule for the way certain items and mechanics functioned before their later changes. There's a lot of debate on whether there's any reason to revisit it since Rebirth is admittedly a more polished and extensive version of it, but I think it has enough of its own style and vibe to be worth checking out even in spite of Rebirth's superiority.

121032079.review:
If I could travel back in time to ask myself what possessed me to pick of [b]The Binding of Isaac[/b] nearly eleven years ago, I doubt I'd be able to discern whether I had a deep-seated need for a reminder of religious and familial trauma or I felt myself some sort of edgelord. I suppose those two options are hardly mutually exclusive though.

For a title so aggressively grotesque, I truly believe that it doesn't get enough of the credit it deserves. Beneath what I can only describe as a nightmare-fueled haze from the mind of Edmund McMillen lies a perfect video-game. I mean, I'd love to ask him what possessed him to come up with this in the first place, but that may be a head-first dive into the mouth of madness. This title amounts to a thinly-veiled retelling of the biblical story of Isaac [i](for those Christians reading at home, it's in that religious text that you've never bothered to actually read)[/i] with some morbid artistic licensing to add more flavor. It is a perfect blend of arcade-style playing and roguelike mechanics.

I can't justifiably complain about anything that [i]The Binding of Isaac[/i] has to offer. Between its Cronenberg-inspired body horror and nearly limitless replay value, this game has so much to offer. Mind you, you've got to have the stomach for it, as it is not for the feint of heart, despite its cartoon veneer.

120160953.review:
The twisted biblical theme is what draws you in. You play as Isaac, Magdalene, Cain and even Judas. You find crosses and rosaries, angels and demons. You fight the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, you fight Satan, but above all - you fight your own mother. All along being bombarded with all types of bodily fluids, drugs and self-harm contraptions. I think the message here is pretty clear, and I absolutely love it. Games ARE meant to be this influential.

But hey, the themes serve merely as the initial attraction. What keeps you playing is the exceptional roguelike gameplay loop, whose randomness keeps you on your toes at all times. The inexhaustible hope (and lust) for an amazing build makes you want to try your best every run. And the feeling you get when all the stars align just right is inimitable and... completely intoxicating. This game can be addictive as hell (pun intended), and that's its best quality.

However, as much as I appreciate this game for what it is and what it brought into the roguelike genre, it is no secret that it has been surpassed long ago, by its own developer no less. In November 2014, Edmund McMillen has shown us what The Binding of Isaac should look like all along. The humongous hate that the Eternal Update received can be mostly boiled down to the fact that after coming back to this 2011 classic from the smooth and inviting Rebirth, all of the original game's faults have suddenly resurfaced for many people, the effect of which was very jarring. The flash original IS janky and sometimes frustrating solely due to its technical quirks. Hence, even though I believe The Binding of Isaac to be amazing, I still admit that in the long run, Rebirth is the way.

All in all, the original Isaac holds a special place in my heart. Writing this short review made me realise how much I appreciate this game, despite its obvious technical flaws. If not for this piece of lovable junk, we wouldn't have Rebirth, nor Enter the Gungeon, nor even the 2020 masterpiece Hades. Oh, wow. Finally Isaac is not the only one shedding a tear or two :')

119026683.review:
I have no idea why this game gets the praise it does. The only redeeming factor of this game is the design.
It's dark, but beautiful. I love how each item changes your character to look more grotesque. And I love the plot. But that's where the positives stop.

- It's practically a bullet hell game, yet there's no dodge feature.

- Most of the items themselves are lame and NOTHING tells you what ANYTHING does, so you'll have to wiki-search every 5 minutes if you don't want to risk ruining your run.

- Some rooms are filled with traps and fast enemies, so since you can't dodge you'll be forced to face-tank everything and lose 8 hearts. And if you didn't find any extra hearts yet, game over.

- The shooting mechanic as a whole is an absolute joke. You can only shoot in 2 planes; up/down, left/right.
so combine that with the fact that you can't dodge leaves you completely bamboozled on this choice for even a semi-bullet hell game. Did I mention enemies CAN shoot in any direction?

There's even more BS, and the game doesn't have a tutorial besides how to move, which would be second-nature to gamers anyway. So you'll have to put in the time to figure out just how much garbage this game has to offer.
Do you want an actual good roguelike/lite bullet-hell? Play "Enter The Gungeon."
It's practically perfect. And that's coming from a guy who's done literally everything there is to do in it.

This is my opinion. Maybe you'll like the game. But I assure you the hardest part about this game is NOT the enemies. It's the ridiculous mechanics.

After going through the process of 100% this game I can safely say its still a amazing game that is more than worth the price. 
-Pro's:
Amazing replay ability.
Fun Mechanics.
Hours of content before having to replay anything.
Challenging but not frustrating.
-Con's:
Has a fair amount of glitches, Both in favour and against the player.
Has aged since it was released.
Has a newer more detailed and in depth version that albeit is more expensive.

Overall I would definitely recommend picking up this game as its a lot of fun in its own right but also serves as a taster for The Binding of Isaac Rebirth which is the newer updated version. The Value for money is insane with this only costing £3.99 and often times is on sale for up to 50% off yet you could get around 100 hours of game play if you are new to the game or genre.

118074513.review:
Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself, drawing pictures, and playing with his toys, as his mom watched christian broadcasts on the television.
Life was simple, and they were both happy. That was until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above;
"Your son has become corrupted by sin! He needs to be saved!"
"I will do my best to save him, my lord" his mother replied, Rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life.
Again, the voice called to her; "Isaac's soul is still corrupt! He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world, and confess his sins!" "I will follow your instructions lord, I have faith in thee" Isaac's mother replied, as she locked Isaac in his room, away from the evils of the world.
One last time, Isaac's mom heard the voice of god calling to her; "You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you"
"Yes lord, anything" Isaac's mother begged. "To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice, your son Isaac will be this sacrifice. Go into his room, and end his life as an offering to me to prove you love me above all else"
"Yes lord" she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen.
Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear.
Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trap door to the basement, hidden under his rug.
Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down, into the unknown depths below.

The game is addictive and pretty hard, but doesn't offer any positive emotions, even if you're succeeding in it.
You are NOT in control of what's happening around you. Gameplay is highly based on RNG.
There is small to zero satisfaction from fulfilling challenges or finishing the game itself, because at the end of the day you'll always feel like randomization went well for you this time and that was a huge chunk of your success, not you becoming better.

I'm the kind of player that likes to take his time, make a plan, learn and react. Games that are heavily based on RNG like this one will not serve such deep satisfaction like finishing a complex story in RPG, beating a boss in souls-like or conquering the opponent in RTS.
The success here doesn't feel earned and the failure feels unfair. This game is a time eater which doesn't reward you well for the time you spent on it.

I will keep playing it because unfortunately I fell for its charm, but you, don't be a lazy b*tch. Go and try some games that require several hours to learn what's going on around you and another several hours to feel comfy in the game world - these are the games that pay out well, these are the games that will show you what it's like to EARN a win. I mean... just go and play Dark Souls lol

116686068.review:
I'd rather a neutral review to better put my feelings towards it, although the more bloated and RNG heavy Rebirth was becoming with each new DLC I really started looking back at this version with greater sentiment.

For a generic description if you've somehow never heard of Isaac before: It's a rouge-like game with a very [i]special[/i] art design and lore featuring all the gross, disgusting...and christian? Yep, it's more or less a story of a child and its imagination twisted with fear and religious teachings but for expert lore I'd suggest checking YT ^^".
Gameplay wise it's all about clearing each room you enter, collect items, beat boss, repeat on next stage till the end. All this while trying not to die as this game is not easy. If you fail you have to start over. Some will love this idea, some won't so do make sure if its your cup of tea.

Technically Rebirth is, despite all, a technically superior product, however the original has its upsides regardless:
+it's much smaller. As said Rebirth may feel overdone and over-saturated with content, too big item pools, ever more extreme achievements... This however is very compact in comparison but even then the RNG with items is a factor.
+Unique looks. Smooth, not on-purpose pixelated art design. It's simply oddly pleasant to look at in its own, well visible and obvious grotesque
+Superior soundtrack. In my opinion it fits and works much better for this game than orchestrated Rebirth's which often felt like too much for what is on the screen. But each to their own here.

But then there are the downsides:
-It's old and made in flash which means 30fps lock and stability issues. Hell, for some may not function at all or have achievement issues.
-RNG heavy in the end, despite all.
-Don't be fooled, it's very difficult which may be a major roadblock in 100%-ing. Though no oddities like beating all bosses without being hit once like Rebirth has. Just no-dmg achievs per vanilla stage but on the other paw this one doesn't have many cheese strats and none are very safe.

I feel these are the biggest bullet points about this entry. I'm quite on a fence since it was my introduction into the genre but on the other paw I have personal reasons to not like the genre...but then I don't really know is it game's or genre's fault ^^"

115788205.review:
I played the game with WOTL so most of the things I say in this review also include WOTL.

FUN -8/10
Game is very fun. Not much to say really.

REPLAYABILITY AND CONTENT - 7/10
While being way less replayable than Rebirth, it's still pretty replayable with near 200 items and 2 final bosses with the WOTL DLC. There is also 7 characters with WOTL (and like half of them suck), which is an OK amount. WOTL also adds 10 challenges, which half of them are barely challenging (a challenge with Dr Fetus isn't challenging when its a free win item in this game) but whatever. Overall, its pretty replayable.

ART STYLE - 9/10
I really like the art style. It's unique due to the fact that not a lot of games use this type of art style and it is fitting since the game looks like a child's drawings.

SOUNDTRACK - 10/10
Soundtrack is great, especially the final boss tracks, the basement and the cellar tracks and the main menu track.

DIFFICULTY AND DESIGN - 3/10
Game is pretty challenging but also pretty unfair (which is why dark boy is like one of the hardest achievements IMO). For example, if your damage is low, then a 5 charger room with 3 corridors can result in you taking unavoidable damage. And I think there isn't enough damage and tears upgrades in the boss pool. There are literally more shot speed ups than tears and damage ups in the boss pool. And there is way too many bloat items and even the devil deals, which are like the best pool in this game, still suck. Overall, I think the game's design is lacking and the difficulty is too unfair.

CONCLUSION - 37/50
Despite its design not being good and its difficulty being unfair, I still think the game is really fun and that both its art style and soundtrack is great and its pretty good at replayability. And I think the price makes this game a great buy.

However at the same time, the game is horribly unbalanced and unpolished with lots of unfair room layouts, and playing it while knowing how much better Repentance is, feels like pure pain. 

I have completed both flash Isaac and Repentance and must say, that while its fascinating to see where the game started, it does not feel good to play, at least not nearly as satisfying as Repentance. Flash Isaac is soul-crushingly difficult and all the differences between the games paint a major contrast in the experiences. 

I must acknowledge though that Flash Isaac, as bullshit as it is, has it's own kind of unique charm. 

In conclusion, I would say this is a game that is worth being aware of, but not worth playing yourself. Stick to Rebirth and it's expansions, namely Repentance, instead. That is a much better, fulfilling and more satisfying gaming experience.

114791385.review:
Really bland and frustrating!
The Story revolves around Issac making his way down the basement trying to escape his mother that's trying to kill him. There isn't really any characters to talk about so this section isn't necessary. The story itself is fine and does move things along, however there isn't really anything special or interesting about it. While it might be a interesting twist on an old story, it never develops into anything great. 
The setting of the basement and the different rooms that you go through are really boring with no a lot of stuff going on in them. While the more you go down the darker it goes, the layout of the levels is uninteresting with there pretty much being only the enemies and some rocks to provide both cover and an obstacle for the player. There are rooms for different purposes that have some form of a change, but even these don't offer anything enjoyable. 
Visually, its a bit iffy. The art direction that these types of games go for are pretty decent as they are pretty simplistic, but do offer some interesting character designs, but it seems that this didn't translate to the levels of the game and sometimes so of the other things such as items are pretty boring to look at. 
Sound and Audio aren't great either with the soundtrack being serviceable and the audio for things such as the tears and enemies are a bit pathetic. 
In terms of gameplay, this has got to be some of the most frustrating controls that I've had to use. The way that Issac and enemies move about in game is very stiff and janky which makes for a really annoying experience. This also effects the way Issac fires as he can only shoot in 4 directions making it hell to position with an enemy and with the way that they move this makes it one of the worst combat experiences I've experienced in recent memory. I think the items and buffs that you can earn in the game can be quite useful, but this can be handicapped due to the poor controls. The only thing i could commend about this game are the bosses as they are designed really well and have unique attack patters, but these can also be beaten easily with the use of bombs as they tend to be a bit overpowered. 
Overall, The Binding of Issac was a really poor game with little to offer and I'm hoping that the rebirth version rectifies to issues that i had with this version

Whenever I play this game I always feel encouraged towards my skills as a gamer and have loads of fun collecting the items throughout this 'dungeon' game, which are completely randomized. 

Best way to play this game:
One window open of the game, 
One minimized window open for the BindingofIsaac Wiki,
Then stop playing once you start hating it.

I just can't with this game. So I will place here a recipe for huckleberry pancakes instead.

Huckleberry pancakes.

1 3/4 cups all purpose white flour
4 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups of buttermilk
5 tablespoon butter, melted
2 large eggs
1/2 cup Huckleberries
In medium bowl combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt, set aside. In small bowl combine buttermilk, butter and eggs. Add buttermilk mixture to the flour mixture, combine until mixed do not over mix (I prefer to use a whisk it does the best job). Fry at 400 degrees. Pour about 1/4 cup of batter on the griddle and sprinkle with the huckleberries.

Cook on first side about 3 minutes until bubbles appear along the edge of the pancake. Flip and cook for 2 minutes more and golden brown. Serve with a big pat of butter, and some pure maple syrup ( get the real stuff it is worth it).
